award_name.ja: 日本農業気象学会学術賞

paper_title.en: Exchange Of CO2 and Heat Between Mangrove Forest and The Atmosphere In Wet and Dry Seasons In Southern Thailand

description.en: Characteristics of CO2 and heat fluxes over a mangrove forest are investigated during dry and wet seasons in southern Thailand. Fluxes are estimated by the modified gradient method presented in Monji et al. (2002). Turbulent fluxes show considerable differences between wet and dry seasons. When it rains the latent heat flux exceeds the net radiation considerably and the sensible heat flux shows large negative values. CO2 flux during the rain is slightly upward. The relationship between global solar radiation and CO2 flux was not significantly different between dry and wet seasons. CO2 stored inside the canopy atmosphere during the night was found to be consumed in the morning by its photosynthesis. The storage rate is large when wind is low and its magnitude is not negligible in the CO2 exchange process. © 2002, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: CO2 and Water Vapor Flux Evaluations by Modified Gradient Methods Over a Mangrove Forest

description.en: Two types of the modified gradient method for CO2 and water vapor flux estimation, in which the eddy correlation is applied only to the sensible heat flux, are presented. One type uses the eddy diffusivity for the sensible heat flux, and the other establishes the flux-gradient relation in the form of the product Φm Φh as a function of the gradient Richardson number. The latter method can be used even in heavy rains. In order to confirm the applicability of these methods, the dimensionless profile relations for momentum, sensible heat, latent heat and CO2 are estimated over a mangrove forest. Although these dimensionless profiles indicate smaller values than the Businger-Dyer representation under stable conditions, they indicate similar tendency with each other. The two modified gradient methods agree with each other although the scatter in the individual comparison is large. © 2002, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Effects of Foliage and Sky View Factor on the Urban Thermal Environment.

description.ja:
We investigated the effects of urban sky view factor and foliage view factor on the thermal environment, based on field experiments in the street canyons of Osaka. Mean radiation temperature (MRT) and physiologically equivalent temperature (PET) are used as the indices of the thermal environment. We found that MRT and PET decrease with a decrease in the sky view factor and with an increase in foliage view factor. The difference of 0.22 in the sky view factor caused a difference of 23°C in PET. A difference of about 0.27 to 0.35 in the foliage view factor caused a difference of about 8.2 to 9.0°C in PET.
We tried to convert the effect of wind speed to that of the foliage and found that an increase of about 3ms-1 in wind speed is necessary to obtain the same effect as a change in the foliage view factor from 0.27 to 0.35.
description.en:
We investigated the effects of urban sky view factor and foliage view factor on the thermal environment, based on field experiments in the street canyons of Osaka. Mean radiation temperature (MRT) and physiologically equivalent temperature (PET) are used as the indices of the thermal environment. We found that MRT and PET decrease with a decrease in the sky view factor and with an increase in foliage view factor. The difference of 0.22 in the sky view factor caused a difference of 23°C in PET. A difference of about 0.27 to 0.35 in the foliage view factor caused a difference of about 8.2 to 9.0°C in PET.
We tried to convert the effect of wind speed to that of the foliage and found that an increase of about 3ms-1 in wind speed is necessary to obtain the same effect as a change in the foliage view factor from 0.27 to 0.35.

paper_title.en: A New, Low-Power Consumption, One-Dimensional Sonic Anemometer-thermometer

description.en: A low power (0.1 W) and light weight (probe weight 270 g and circuit weight 80 g) one dimensional sonic anemometer-thermometer was developed. The measuring span of the anemometer is 10 cm, sound frequency is 40 kHz and alternation frequency of the sound direction is 78 Hz. The low power consumption was attained by using ceramic transducers, which can be driven by low voltage pulses (5 V peak-to-peak) and by adapting CMOS logic to the circuit. A field test was carried out in a coniferous forest with a commercial sonic anemometer and a fine thermocouple thermometer. Comparison of the output signal and spectra from each sonic anemometer indicated good agreement. The characteristics of the sonic anemometer-thermometer are low power consumption and light weight. These features are useful for measurements from a small tethered balloon or at places where the electrical power is limited. © 1999, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Spatial Variability of Urban Surface Heat Fluxes Estimated from Landsat TM Data Under Summer and Winter Conditions

description.en: This paper proposes a method to estimate the urban surface heat fluxes using Landsat TM data in conjunction with routine data from meteorological observatory and direct field measurement data. The sensible and latent heat fluxes are evaluated independently using bulk transfer formulae. The ground cover classification, surface albedo, surface temperature and the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) are deduced from two Landsat TM images on Aug. 6, 1990 and Dec. 6, 1988. A field measurement is carried out to obtain the relationship between the moisture availability and relative humidity for no-vegetation ground using band-pass covariance technique to measure the turbulent sensible and latent heat fluxes over concrete surface. The distribution of each pixel and mean value for each kind of ground cover show that the net radiation in urban area has a relatively conservative behavior with little spatial variability. Conversely, the sensible and latent heat fluxes have clear spatial variability. The high sensible heat flux corresponds to high building (urban center) and residential area, while the relatively low sensible heat flux corresponds to forest area in parks and open water. The latent heat flux is very low in high building and wooden residential area (mean values less than 37 Wm-2 in summer and 1 Wm-2 in winter). But in residential area with some vegetation and forest area, latent heat flux increases to 77 and 194 Wm-2, and the mean Bowen ratio decreases to 4.6 and 1.6 in summer, respectively. Since the amount and activity of vegetation is higher in summer, there is a greater spatial variability of heat fluxes in summer than in winter. © 1998, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

衛星データを用いた生駒山地における森林熱収支の季節変化の評価(共著)

paper_title.en: Development of a Mini-Sonde System for Measuring Trace Gas Fluxes with the REA Method

description.en: A small Sonde system for measuring trace gas fluxes with the relaxed eddy accumulation method installed below a tethered balloon was developed. The system consists of mainly three parts: sensors, a microcomputer and a sampling unit. The sensors are a one-dimensional sonic anemometer for measuring the vertical wind component, a fine wire thermocouple thermometer for measuring the mean and fluctuations of temperature, and a cup anemometer for measuring mean wind speed. The microcomputer processes and stores the meteorological signals and also controls the apparatus with a BASIC program. Total weight including the gimbal system is 1.5kg. Preliminary measurements of the fluxes of sensible heat, CO2 and CH4 were carried out. © 1997, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

paper_title.ja: STATISTICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF CYCLONES IN BANGLADESH AND APPLICATION OF OBJECTIVE ANALYSIS FOR THE PERIOD 1981 TO 1994
paper_title.en: Statistical characteristics of cyclones in Bangladesh and application of objective analysis for the period 1981 to 1994(共著)

ja.name: Disaster Prevention Research Institute Kyoto University
College of Agriculture University of Osaka Prefecture
General Education and Research Kyoto Sangyo University
Department of Geography Graduate School University of Tokyo
Institute of Flood Control and Drainage Research Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology

en.name: Disaster Prevention Research Institute Kyoto University
College of Agriculture University of Osaka Prefecture
General Education and Research Kyoto Sangyo University
Department of Geography Graduate School University of Tokyo
Institute of Flood Control and Drainage Research Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology

description.ja: Statistical features of cyclones in Bangladesh in the 14 recent years (1981-1994) are summarized from various statistical published data. Eleven cyclones struck Bangladesh, including four severe ones of hurricane intensity which caused large amounts of damage in the coastal area of Bangladesh. Seasonal variations in the occurrence of cyclonic storms in the Bay of Bengal are made clear climatologically. The method developed for the objective analysis of typhoons in Japan is applied to three typical cyclones in Bangladesh. The pressure and high wind field in these cyclones could be estimated using this method. More meteorological data for the Bay of Bengal and neighboring countries, however, are necessary to make a more precise simulation.

paper_title.ja: CO<sub>2</sub> and Heat Exchange of Mangrove Forest in Thailand
paper_title.en: CO<sub>2</sub> and heat exchange of mangrove forest in Thailand(共著)

description.ja: CO<sub>2</sub> and heat fluxes of the mangrove forest in Thailand are investigated based on observation during a dry season. Clear diurnal change was seen in the sensible heat flux. There was a large amount of latent heat flux even at night. The latent heat flux was larger than the sensible heat flux. CO<sub>2</sub> flux changed sign between day and night. The magnitude of the upward flux during nighttime and the downward flux during daytime was about the same, which is considerably different from the flux characteristics during the wet season.
description.en: CO<sub>2</sub> and heat fluxes of the mangrove forest in Thailand are investigated based on observation during a dry season. Clear diurnal change was seen in the sensible heat flux. There was a large amount of latent heat flux even at night. The latent heat flux was larger than the sensible heat flux. CO<sub>2</sub> flux changed sign between day and night. The magnitude of the upward flux during nighttime and the downward flux during daytime was about the same, which is considerably different from the flux characteristics during the wet season.

paper_title.en: Seasonal Change of heat budget in forest area derived from Landsat/TM data(共著)
A System Of The Relaxed Eddy Accumulation Method To Evaluate CO2 Flux Over Plant Canopies

description.en: A sampling system based on the relaxed eddy accumulation method for continuous trace gas flux measurement was developed. The system consists of a sonic anemometer, a Teflon diaphragm pump, delay circuits, and a differential gas analyzer. Test measurements for the CO2 flux were carried out over a coniferous forest and a paddy field. The empirical coefficient was determined by comparing with the fluxes measured by the eddy correlation method. This coefficient may be considered practically as a constant (0.57). © 1996, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Characteristics Of CO2 Flux over a Mangrove Forest of Southern Thailand in Rainy Season

description.en: An experiment was conducted to find out the characteristics of CO2 flux in a mangrove forest of Thailand during the rainy season. The relaxed eddy accumulation method was applied to the measurement of the CO2 flux over the forest. The CO2 flux increased with solar radiation, and the daytime downward CO2 flux was -0.5~-1.0 mg m-2 s-1 for the global radiation 400~800 Wm-2, which is about the same magnitude as the typical values obtained in other tropical or temperate forests. The soil respiration was an order of magnitude smaller in the mangrove forest compared to other forests. © 1996, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.
